title: List of sunken battlecruisers
text:
Sunken battlecruisers are large <a href="capital%20ship">capital ship</a>s built in the first half of the 20th century that were either destroyed in battle, <a href="Scuttling">scuttled</a>, or destroyed in a weapon test. They were similar in size and cost to a <a href="battleship">battleship</a>, and typically carried the same kind of heavy guns, but battlecruisers generally carried less armor and were faster. The first <a href="battlecruiser">battlecruiser</a>s were developed in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> in the first decade of the century, as a development of the <a href="armored%20cruiser">armored cruiser</a>, at the same time the <a href="dreadnought">dreadnought</a> succeeded the <a href="pre-dreadnought%20battleship">pre-dreadnought battleship</a>. The original aim of the battlecruiser was to hunt down slower, older armored cruisers and destroy them with heavy gunfire. However, as more and more battlecruisers were built, their opponents became ships of their own type, not slower, weaker vessels.
In <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, the thin armor of British battlecruisers did not serve them well in combat with their better-armored German counterparts and three were lost at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Jutland">Battle of Jutland</a> in 1916. <a href="SMS%20L%C3%BCtzow">SMS "Lützow"</a>, a German battlecruiser, was also sunk during the battle. Five German battlecruisers were scuttled by their crews in 1919 to prevent their seizure by the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> after the <a href="First%20Armistice%20at%20Compi%C3%A8gne">First Armistice at Compiègne</a> in 1918.
Between the World Wars, the <a href="Washington%20Naval%20Treaty">Washington Naval Treaty</a> of 1922 limited the number and tonnage of capital ships that could be retained. Many battlecruisers were <a href="Ship%20breaking">scrapped</a> during this period, though <a href="HMAS%20Australia%20%281911%29">HMAS "Australia"</a>, the sole Australian battlecruiser, was scuttled to comply with the treaty. One provision of the treaty allowed nations to convert two battlecruisers then under construction into aircraft carriers and both the Empire of Japan and the United States took advantage of the opportunity. The British also converted all three of their "light battlecruisers" into aircraft carriers even though they were not subject to the treaty. The Japanese rebuilt their four remaining battlecruisers into <a href="fast%20battleship">fast battleship</a>s during the 1930s.
<a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> took a heavy toll on the remaining battlecruisers, both converted and unconverted. In contrast to World War I, where all four ships were lost to gunfire, only two were sunk solely by guns. Two battlecruisers were sunk by a combination of gunfire and aerial attack, four were sunk solely by aircraft and two were sunk by submarines. The largest loss of life in the sinking of a battlecruiser was the 1,415 killed in the sinking of <a href="HMS%20Hood">HMS "Hood"</a> during her confrontation with the in 1941. Of the three surviving World War II battlecruisers, two were <a href="Ship%20breaking">scrapped</a> after the war and one, , was sunk by <a href="nuclear%20weapon">nuclear weapon</a> tests in 1946.
Losses.
The first combat losses of battlecruisers occurred during World War I, as a result of the Battle of Jutland between the Royal Navy and the <a href="Imperial%20German%20Navy">Imperial German Navy</a> on 31 May 1916. The three British ships—, , and —were all sunk by <a href="magazine%20%28artillery%29">magazine</a> explosions, with heavy loss of life. had been hit several times below the <a href="waterline">waterline</a> by British shells during the battle and took on a lot of water after the battle. Later that night, "Lützow" had so much water aboard that she threatened to <a href="capsize">capsize</a>; the crew was ordered to abandon ship and a German <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a> finished her off with two <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es. The next combat losses were a quarter century later during World War II, when the British intercepted a German force attempting to break out into the Atlantic to attack supply convoys. Shortly after the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Denmark%20Strait">Battle of the Denmark Strait</a> began on 24 May 1941, a shell from the hit , causing its magazine to explode with massive loss of life. Six months later, the battleship and the battlecruiser attempted to intercept Japanese troop convoys approaching the <a href="Malay%20Peninsula">Malay Peninsula</a>. They were spotted by Japanese aircraft en route and sunk by <a href="torpedo%20bomber">torpedo bomber</a>s on 10 December.
Several battlecruisers survived World War I only to be <a href="scuttling">scuttled</a> in its aftermath. The five German battlecruisers that survived World War I—, , , , —were <a href="interned">interned</a> at <a href="Scapa%20Flow">Scapa Flow</a> pending the signing of a peace treaty between Germany and the <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20I">Allies</a>. The commander of the German ships in Scapa, <a href="Rear%20Admiral">Rear Admiral</a> <a href="Ludwig%20von%20Reuter">Ludwig von Reuter</a>, thought the British were going to seize the ships immediately after the expiration of the <a href="Armistice%20with%20Germany">Armistice</a>, and preemptively ordered the ships be <a href="scuttled">scuttled</a> on the morning of 21 June 1919 to keep them out of British hands. The <a href="Royal%20Australian%20Navy">Royal Australian Navy</a> scuttled in 1924 to comply with the terms of the <a href="Washington%20Naval%20Treaty">Washington Naval Treaty</a>.
Half a dozen of the surviving battlecruisers (including three under construction) were converted into aircraft carriers during the 1920s.
All three of the s were converted. "Courageous"s aircraft were hunting for submarines shortly after the beginning of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> when she was sunk by the on 17 September 1939. The following year, was returning to Britain when she was sunk by the German battleships and in the North Sea on 8 June 1940. A clause in the Washington Naval Treaty allowed two ships per signatory to be converted to aircraft carriers, and the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> chose to convert two of its s during the 1920s because of their high speed. was hit by two bombs and two torpedoes during the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Coral%20Sea">Battle of the Coral Sea</a> on 8 May 1942. They only moderately damaged the ship, but, more importantly, they cracked some of her <a href="avgas">avgas</a> storage tanks. Fumes from these tanks later caught fire and could not be put out; the crew was forced to abandon ship and "Lexington" was torpedoed and sunk by an American destroyer. survived the war, but was considered obsolete so she was used as a target for nuclear weapon tests during <a href="Operation%20Crossroads">Operation Crossroads</a>. The ship survived the first test with little damage, but was sunk by the second test on 25 July 1946. The was another battlecruiser converted into a carrier because of the Washington Naval Treaty. She was struck by three bombs during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Midway">Battle of Midway</a> on 4 June 1942 that caused serious fires that forced the crew to abandon ship early that night. By the following morning, it was clear that the ship could not be repaired, and so was torpedoed and sunk.
The four Japanese s were reconstructed as <a href="fast%20battleship">fast battleship</a>s during the 1930s. On 13 November 1942, during the <a href="First%20Naval%20Battle%20of%20Guadalcanal">First Naval Battle of Guadalcanal</a>, stumbled across American <a href="cruiser">cruiser</a>s and destroyers at <a href="point-blank%20range">point-blank range</a>. The ship was badly damaged in the encounter and had to be towed by her <a href="sister%20ship">sister ship</a> . Both were spotted by American aircraft the following morning and "Kirishima" was forced to cast off her tow because of repeated aerial attacks. "Hiei"s captain ordered her crew to abandon ship after further damage and <a href="scuttled">scuttled</a> "Hiei" in the early evening of 14 November. On the night of 14/15 November during the <a href="Second%20Naval%20Battle%20of%20Guadalcanal">Second Naval Battle of Guadalcanal</a>, "Kirishima" returned to <a href="Ironbottom%20Sound">Ironbottom Sound</a>, but encountered the American battleships and . While failing to detect "Washington", "Kirishima" engaged "South Dakota" with some effect. "Washington" opened fire a few minutes later at short range and badly damaged "Kirishima", knocking out her aft turrets, jamming her rudder, and hitting the ship below the waterline. The flooding proved to be uncontrollable and "Kirishima" capsized three and a half hours later. Returning to Japan after the <a href="Battle%20of%20Leyte%20Gulf">Battle of Leyte Gulf</a>, "Kongō" was torpedoed and sunk by the American submarine on 21 November 1944. "Haruna" was based at <a href="Kure%2C%20Hiroshima">Kure</a>, Japan when the <a href="Bombing%20of%20Kure%20%28July%201945%29">naval base was attacked</a> by British and American carrier aircraft on 24 and 28 July 1945. The ship was only lightly damaged by a single bomb hit on 24 July, but was hit a dozen more times on 28 July and sank at her <a href="pier">pier</a>. She was refloated after the war and scrapped in early 1946.
The listed battlecruisers are grouped according to causes of the sinking. Within groups, they are listed in chronological order of sinking.
Sunk in combat.
The following ships were destroyed in battle.
Scuttled battlecruisers.
Several battlecruisers were <a href="scuttling">scuttled</a>.
Converted battlecruisers.
Several battlecruisers were converted into other ship types either during construction or after entering service; many of these ships were sunk in combat during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
